frames.text: TBK1 promotes T-cell activation
frames.verbose-text: Here we show that T-cell-specific ablation of the kinase TBK1 promotes T-cell activation but causes retention of effector T cells in the draining lymph node in a neuroinflammatory autoimmunity model, experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE).

frames.text: TBK1-stimulated AKT ubiquitination
frames.verbose-text: TBK1 controls the activation of AKT and its downstream kinase mTORC1 by a mechanism involving TBK1-stimulated AKT ubiquitination and degradation.

frames.text: AKT ubiquitination
frames.verbose-text: TBK1 controls the activation of AKT and its downstream kinase mTORC1 by a mechanism involving TBK1-stimulated AKT ubiquitination and degradation.

frames.text: AKT-mTORC1 signalling in turn contributes to enhanced T-cell activation
frames.verbose-text: The deregulated AKT-mTORC1 signalling in turn contributes to enhanced T-cell activation and impaired effector T-cell egress from draining lymph nodes.

frames.text: mice with a small-molecule inhibitor of TBK1 inhibits EAE
frames.verbose-text: Treatment of mice with a small-molecule inhibitor of TBK1 inhibits EAE induction.

frames.text: signal transduction mediated by the TCR and a costimulatory molecule
frames.verbose-text: The T-cell priming and differentiation are governed by signal transduction mediated by the TCR and a costimulatory molecule, CD28, as well as cytokine signals6.

frames.text: signal transduction mediated by the TCR and a costimulatory molecule, CD28
frames.verbose-text: The T-cell priming and differentiation are governed by signal transduction mediated by the TCR and a costimulatory molecule, CD28, as well as cytokine signals6.

frames.text: signal transduction mediated by the TCR
frames.verbose-text: The T-cell priming and differentiation are governed by signal transduction mediated by the TCR and a costimulatory molecule, CD28, as well as cytokine signals6.

frames.text: IKK components mediating activation of the transcription factor NF-κB1213
frames.verbose-text: TBK1 and IKKε share structural homology with IKKα and IKKβ, typical IKK components mediating activation of the transcription factor NF-κB1213.

frames.text: IKK components mediating activation of the transcription
frames.verbose-text: TBK1 and IKKε share structural homology with IKKα and IKKβ, typical IKK components mediating activation of the transcription factor NF-κB1213.

frames.text: TBK1 perturbed T-cell homeostasis
frames.verbose-text: T-cell-specific ablation of TBK1 perturbed T-cell homeostasis, characterized by an increased frequency of T cells with an activated phenotype, and rendered naïve T cells more sensitive to activation by agonistic antibodies for TCR and CD28.

frames.text: expression of TBK1
frames.verbose-text: Our data suggest that TBK1 mediates egress of effector T cells from draining lymph nodes in a mechanism that involves negative regulation of the kinases AKT and mTORC1.ResultsTBK1 is a kinase that responds to T-cell activation signalsOur initial analysis of the BioGPS database revealed that in addition to macrophages, lymphocytes had an abundant expression of TBK1 (data not shown).

frames.text: TBK1-deficient T cells produced remarkably higher levels of IFN-γ
frames.verbose-text: Moreover, the stimulated TBK1-deficient T cells produced remarkably higher levels of IFN-γ, as detected by both enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and flow cytometry assays (Fig. 2b,c).

frames.text: levels of IFN-γ
frames.verbose-text: Moreover, the stimulated TBK1-deficient T cells produced remarkably higher levels of IFN-γ, as detected by both enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and flow cytometry assays (Fig. 2b,c).

frames.text: levels of Th1
frames.verbose-text: The EAE-refractory phenotype of the Tbk1-TKO mice was unlikely due to a defect in inflammatory T-cell production, since the TBK1-deficient CD4+ T cells generated higher levels of Th1 and Th17 cells than WT CD4+ T cells in an in vitro differentiation assay (Supplementary Fig. 3).

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency promotes T-cell activation
frames.verbose-text: These results suggest that although TBK1 deficiency promotes T-cell activation and differentiation, it attenuates EAE induction probably by blocking the migration of the effector T cells from the draining lymph nodes to the CNS.To further investigate the EAE-regulating function of TBK1, we examined the role of TBK1 in regulating migration of autoimmune T cells to the CNS.

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency promotes T-cell activation and differentiation
frames.verbose-text: These results suggest that although TBK1 deficiency promotes T-cell activation and differentiation, it attenuates EAE induction probably by blocking the migration of the effector T cells from the draining lymph nodes to the CNS.To further investigate the EAE-regulating function of TBK1, we examined the role of TBK1 in regulating migration of autoimmune T cells to the CNS.

frames.text: GFP expression
frames.verbose-text: On the basis of GFP expression, we analysed the frequency of WT and Tbk1-TKO T cells in the CNS and draining lymph nodes of the recipient mice during the early effector phase (day 14) of EAE induction.

frames.text: TBK1-deficient T cells in infiltrating into CNS is not due to attenuated CNS
frames.verbose-text: Since the WT and TBK1-deficient T cells were activated under the same conditions, these results suggest that the defect of the TBK1-deficient T cells in infiltrating into CNS is not due to attenuated CNS inflammation but rather due to a cell-intrinsic deficiency.TBK1 deficiency promotes T-cell retention in lymph nodesAntigen-activated T cells are initially retained in draining lymph nodes to undergo differentiation and subsequently exit the lymph nodes and migrate to the peripheral site of infection or inflammation21.

frames.text: TBK1-deficient T cells in infiltrating into CNS is not due to attenuated CNS inflammation
frames.verbose-text: Since the WT and TBK1-deficient T cells were activated under the same conditions, these results suggest that the defect of the TBK1-deficient T cells in infiltrating into CNS is not due to attenuated CNS inflammation but rather due to a cell-intrinsic deficiency.TBK1 deficiency promotes T-cell retention in lymph nodesAntigen-activated T cells are initially retained in draining lymph nodes to undergo differentiation and subsequently exit the lymph nodes and migrate to the peripheral site of infection or inflammation21.

frames.text: loss of TBK1
frames.verbose-text: Since the TBK1-deficient T cells were accumulated in the draining lymph nodes during EAE induction (Fig. 4b), we examined whether the loss of TBK1 affected T-cell egress from the lymph nodes, by employing a mixed T-cell transfer approach.

frames.text: mice only had moderately reduced frequency of CD4+
frames.verbose-text: In an influenza viral infection model, we found that the lung of the virus-infected Tbk1-TKO mice only had moderately reduced frequency of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells and increased frequency of T cells in the draining mediastinal lymph nodes (Supplementary Fig. 4a).

frames.text: expression of Ninj1
frames.verbose-text: Gene expression analysis revealed that the Tbk1-TKO T cells had a moderate reduction in the expression of Ninj1 gene and competent expression of several other cell adhesion molecules and chemokine receptors implicated in T-cell migration into the CNS (Supplementary Fig. 5)222324.

frames.text: TBK1 mediates CNS infiltration
frames.verbose-text: To further assess the mechanism by which TBK1 mediates CNS infiltration of T cells, we compared the migration of the WT and TBK1-deficient T cells by labelling the in vitro-expanded MOG-primed WT and Tbk1-TKO T cells with different fluorescence dyes (CMRA and CFSE, respectively) and transferring them in a mixture (1:1 ratio) into WT mice.

frames.text: TBK1 mediates CNS
frames.verbose-text: To further assess the mechanism by which TBK1 mediates CNS infiltration of T cells, we compared the migration of the WT and TBK1-deficient T cells by labelling the in vitro-expanded MOG-primed WT and Tbk1-TKO T cells with different fluorescence dyes (CMRA and CFSE, respectively) and transferring them in a mixture (1:1 ratio) into WT mice.

frames.text: phosphorylation of Foxo1
frames.verbose-text: The phosphorylation of Foxo1, a known target of AKT25, was also higher in the TBK1-deficient T cells (Fig. 5a).

frames.text: phosphorylation of the mTORC1 substrate protein S6 kinase 1 (S6K1
frames.verbose-text: Consistently, the TBK1-deficient T cells had elevated phosphorylation of the mTORC1 substrate protein S6 kinase 1 (S6K1) as well as the S6K1 substrate S6 (Fig. 5a).

frames.text: phosphorylation of the mTORC1 substrate protein S6 kinase 1 (S6K1) as well as the S6K1 substrate S6
frames.verbose-text: Consistently, the TBK1-deficient T cells had elevated phosphorylation of the mTORC1 substrate protein S6 kinase 1 (S6K1) as well as the S6K1 substrate S6 (Fig. 5a).

frames.text: phosphorylation of the MAP kinases p38 and ERK
frames.verbose-text: In contrast, the loss of TBK1 did not alter the phosphorylation of the MAP kinases p38 and ERK (Supplementary Fig. 6a).

frames.text: hyperphosphorylation of AKT as well as S6
frames.verbose-text: Moreover, we detected hyperphosphorylation of AKT as well as S6 and S6K1 in Tbk1-TKO T cells isolated during the effector phase of EAE induction (Fig. 5c).

frames.text: phosphorylation of AKT and S6
frames.verbose-text: Using the Cre-ER-inducible KO system, we found that TBK1 ablation in adult mice also caused aberrant phosphorylation of AKT and S6 in T cells (Supplementary Fig. 6d), further emphasizing a pivotal role for TBK1 in controlling the activation of AKT and its downstream targets, Foxo1 and mTORC1.TBK1 induces phosphorylation-dependent AKT degradationAlthough AKT activation has been extensively studied, how this master kinase is negatively controlled is unclear.

frames.text: level of total AKT
frames.verbose-text: We found that the hyperactivation of AKT in TBK1-deficient T cells was associated with a profound increase in the level of total AKT protein (Fig. 5a and Supplementary Fig. 6b–d).

frames.text: AKT mRNA expression
frames.verbose-text: This phenotype was not due to enhanced AKT mRNA expression (Supplementary Fig. 6e), indicating a post-translational mechanism of AKT regulation.

frames.text: AKT ubiquitination
frames.verbose-text: Because of the low number of naïve T cells in the Tbk1-TKO mice, we used thymocytes for AKT ubiquitination assays.

frames.text: level of AKT
frames.verbose-text: As seen in peripheral T cells, the TBK1-deficient thymocytes also had elevated level of AKT (Fig. 5d).

frames.text: level of AKT
frames.verbose-text: This finding suggests that TBK1 controls the homeostatic level of AKT by promoting ubiquitin-dependent AKT degradation, thus explaining the accumulation of AKT in the TBK1-deficient T cells.Since the homeostasis of T cells involves constant stimulation of the TCR by self-ligands27, we asked whether the TCR signal could stimulate AKT degradation and whether this signalling event was regulated by TBK1.

frames.text: TCR signal could stimulate AKT
frames.verbose-text: This finding suggests that TBK1 controls the homeostatic level of AKT by promoting ubiquitin-dependent AKT degradation, thus explaining the accumulation of AKT in the TBK1-deficient T cells.Since the homeostasis of T cells involves constant stimulation of the TCR by self-ligands27, we asked whether the TCR signal could stimulate AKT degradation and whether this signalling event was regulated by TBK1.

frames.text: loss of endogenous AKT, which was blocked by a proteasome inhibitor, MG132
frames.verbose-text: Indeed, the expression of TBK1, but not its catalytically inactive mutant (K38A), caused drastic loss of endogenous AKT, which was blocked by a proteasome inhibitor, MG132 (Fig. 5f).

frames.text: TBK1 also induced the proteolytic degradation of exogenously expressed AKT
frames.verbose-text: TBK1 also induced the proteolytic degradation of exogenously expressed AKT but did not affect the co-transfected control protein GFP (Supplementary Fig. 6f).

frames.text: phosphorylates AKT at threonine-195
frames.verbose-text: A previous study suggests that the overexpressed TBK1 phosphorylates AKT at threonine-195 and serine-378, but the functional significance has not been determined29.

frames.text: TBK1 stimulated AKT
frames.verbose-text: Our finding that TBK1 stimulated AKT degradation led us to examine whether these phosphorylation sites regulate TBK1 stability.

frames.text: AKT only weakly inhibited TBK1
frames.verbose-text: Mutation of threonine-195, or the activation-loop phosphorylation site threonine-308, of AKT only weakly inhibited TBK1-stimulated degradation (Fig. 5g).

frames.text: TBK1-induced AKT phosphorylation at serine-378
frames.verbose-text: These results indicate that the TBK1-induced AKT phosphorylation at serine-378 plays an important role in regulating the fate of AKT.Functional significance of AKT-mTORC1 deregulationOur finding that TBK1 controls the activation of AKT and mTORC1 provides molecular insight into the impaired T-cell homeostasis in Tbk1-TKO mice, since the AKT-mTORC1 signalling axis has a crucial role in the regulation of T-cell homeostasis26.

frames.text: AKT phosphorylation at serine-378
frames.verbose-text: These results indicate that the TBK1-induced AKT phosphorylation at serine-378 plays an important role in regulating the fate of AKT.Functional significance of AKT-mTORC1 deregulationOur finding that TBK1 controls the activation of AKT and mTORC1 provides molecular insight into the impaired T-cell homeostasis in Tbk1-TKO mice, since the AKT-mTORC1 signalling axis has a crucial role in the regulation of T-cell homeostasis26.

frames.text: mTORC1 inhibitor, rapamycin, blocked the homeostatic activation of mTORC1
frames.verbose-text: Indeed, we found that treatment of Tbk1-TKO mice with an mTORC1 inhibitor, rapamycin, blocked the homeostatic activation of mTORC1 and corrected the T-cell homeostasis phenotype (Fig. 5i).

frames.text: mice with an mTORC1 inhibitor, rapamycin, blocked the homeostatic activation of mTORC1
frames.verbose-text: Indeed, we found that treatment of Tbk1-TKO mice with an mTORC1 inhibitor, rapamycin, blocked the homeostatic activation of mTORC1 and corrected the T-cell homeostasis phenotype (Fig. 5i).

frames.text: expression of S1PR1
frames.verbose-text: It is known that activated T cells initially downregulate homing receptors, particularly sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor 1 (S1PR1), and then regain the expression of S1PR1 for migrating out of the lymph nodes21.

frames.text: Akt, which reduced the level of AKT and P-AKT
frames.verbose-text: Interestingly, ablation of one allele of Akt, which reduced the level of AKT and P-AKT in Tbk1-TKO T cells (Fig. 5j), largely restored the sensitivity of the Tbk1-TKO mice to EAE induction (Fig. 5k) as well as the CNS migration of the Tbk1-TKO T cells (Fig. 5l).

frames.text: level of AKT and P-AKT
frames.verbose-text: Interestingly, ablation of one allele of Akt, which reduced the level of AKT and P-AKT in Tbk1-TKO T cells (Fig. 5j), largely restored the sensitivity of the Tbk1-TKO mice to EAE induction (Fig. 5k) as well as the CNS migration of the Tbk1-TKO T cells (Fig. 5l).

frames.text: expression of the transcription factor KLF2
frames.verbose-text: A hallmark of the CNS-migrating autoimmune T cells is the high level expression of the transcription factor KLF2 and its target gene S1PR1, the latter of which has become an attractive target for MS therapy243031.

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency only moderately reduced the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1
frames.verbose-text: In naïve CD4+ T cells, the TBK1 deficiency only moderately reduced the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1 as well as two other T-cell homing genes, CCR7 and CD62L (Fig. 5m).

frames.text: expression of KLF2 and S1PR1
frames.verbose-text: In naïve CD4+ T cells, the TBK1 deficiency only moderately reduced the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1 as well as two other T-cell homing genes, CCR7 and CD62L (Fig. 5m).

frames.text: expression of KLF2
frames.verbose-text: In naïve CD4+ T cells, the TBK1 deficiency only moderately reduced the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1 as well as two other T-cell homing genes, CCR7 and CD62L (Fig. 5m).

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency only moderately reduced the expression of KLF2
frames.verbose-text: In naïve CD4+ T cells, the TBK1 deficiency only moderately reduced the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1 as well as two other T-cell homing genes, CCR7 and CD62L (Fig. 5m).

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency greatly inhibited the expression of KLF2
frames.verbose-text: Interestingly, however, the TBK1 deficiency greatly inhibited the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1, although only moderately reduced expression of CCR7 and CD62L, in the memory population of CD4+ T cells (Fig. 5m).

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency greatly inhibited the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1
frames.verbose-text: Interestingly, however, the TBK1 deficiency greatly inhibited the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1, although only moderately reduced expression of CCR7 and CD62L, in the memory population of CD4+ T cells (Fig. 5m).

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency greatly inhibited the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1, although only moderately reduced expression of CCR7
frames.verbose-text: Interestingly, however, the TBK1 deficiency greatly inhibited the expression of KLF2 and S1PR1, although only moderately reduced expression of CCR7 and CD62L, in the memory population of CD4+ T cells (Fig. 5m).

frames.text: level of surface expression of S1PR1
frames.verbose-text: Flow cytometry analyses also revealed reduced level of surface expression of S1PR1 in Tbk1-TKO CD4+ T cells (Fig. 5n).

frames.text: expression of KLF2 is known to be mediated by Foxo1
frames.verbose-text: The expression of KLF2 is known to be mediated by Foxo1, a transcription factor that is negatively regulated by AKT32.

frames.text: expression of KLF2
frames.verbose-text: Interestingly, incubation of Tbk1-TKO CD4+ T cells with small-molecule inhibitors for AKT (AKTi) and its upstream regulator PI3 kinase (LY294002) greatly promoted the expression of KLF2 (Fig. 5o).

frames.text: Tbk1-TKO CD4+ T cells with small-molecule inhibitors for AKT (AKTi) and its upstream regulator PI3 kinase (LY294002) greatly promoted the expression of KLF2
frames.verbose-text: Interestingly, incubation of Tbk1-TKO CD4+ T cells with small-molecule inhibitors for AKT (AKTi) and its upstream regulator PI3 kinase (LY294002) greatly promoted the expression of KLF2 (Fig. 5o).

frames.text: expression of KLF2
frames.verbose-text: On the other hand, these inhibitors only slightly increased the expression of KLF2 in the WT T cells (Fig. 5o), consistent with the low basal AKT activity in WT T cells (Fig. 5a).

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency attenuated the expression of KLF2

frames.text: TBK1 expression
frames.verbose-text: In parallel with the functional studies, we analysed the potential alterations of TBK1 expression in MS patients.

frames.text: expression of TBK1
frames.verbose-text: Our data revealed that the expression of TBK1 is significantly increased in the peripheral blood mononuclear cell (PBMC) of MS patients compared with the healthy donors (Supplementary Fig. 7e).

frames.text: TBK1 expression
frames.verbose-text: Consistently, TBK1 expression was also shown to be elevated (2.41- and 1.79-folds) in two MS PBMC microarray databases3435.

frames.text: amlexanox treatment drastically delayed the onset, and reduced the severity, of the EAE disease (Fig. 6a), which was associated with a profound reduction in the number of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in the CNS of the EAE-induced mice
frames.verbose-text: The amlexanox treatment drastically delayed the onset, and reduced the severity, of the EAE disease (Fig. 6a), which was associated with a profound reduction in the number of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in the CNS of the EAE-induced mice (Fig. 6b).

frames.text: amlexanox treatment greatly inhibited the EAE relapse
frames.verbose-text: Importantly, the amlexanox treatment greatly inhibited the EAE relapse (Fig. 6e).

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency promotes T-cell activation and differentiation
frames.verbose-text: Although the TBK1 deficiency promotes T-cell activation and differentiation, the Tbk1-TKO mice are refractory to the induction of EAE, an animal model of the autoimmune neuroinflammatory disease MS.We obtained genetic and biochemical evidences that TBK1 served as a negative regulator of AKT.

frames.text: TBK1 deficiency attenuated Foxo1 activation and KLF2 expression
frames.verbose-text: Indeed, the TBK1 deficiency attenuated Foxo1 activation and KLF2 expression in T cells, indicating the involvement of these transcription factors in the perturbed T-cell homeostasis in the Tbk1-TKO mice.Migration of autoimmune T cells from lymphoid organs to the target tissues represents a crucial and complex step in the development of autoimmunity.

frames.text: Foxo1, which is negatively regulated by AKT
frames.verbose-text: The transcription factor Foxo1, which is negatively regulated by AKT, has been implicated in the induction of KLF2 and other migration-regulatory genes384243.

frames.text: TBK1 promotes T-cell migration
frames.verbose-text: We propose that TBK1 promotes T-cell migration by downregulating AKT and, thereby, maintaining a sufficient level of active Foxo1 for mediating the expression of migration genes.

frames.text: Foxo1 phosphorylation
frames.verbose-text: Indeed, we found that TBK1 deficiency causes elevated Foxo1 phosphorylation in T cells.It is important to note that the TBK1 deficiency only partially impaired the lymph node egress of T cells.

frames.text: TBK1 regulates T-cell homeostasis and mediates T-cell migration
frames.verbose-text: While TBK1 regulates T-cell homeostasis and mediates T-cell migration into the CNS, IKKε is dispensable for these biological functions.

frames.text: level of AKT
frames.verbose-text: In TBK1-deficient T cells, the steady level of AKT is drastically elevated, which contributes to the aberrant AKT activity in naïve and effector T cells.

frames.text: TBK1-stimulated AKT
frames.verbose-text: We have obtained biochemical evidence that the serine-378 phosphorylation site of AKT is crucial for TBK1-stimulated AKT degradation.Our work not only demonstrated a novel signalling mechanism that regulates T-cell homeostasis and EAE pathogenesis but also have profound implications for MS therapy.

frames.text: TBK1 knockdown in human PBMCs causes hyperactivation of AKT-mTORC1 signalling and reduced expression of the T-cell homing genes KFL2

arguments.text: expression of the T-cell homing genes KFL2

frames.verbose-text: Regarding the human relevance of our findings, we found that TBK1 knockdown in human PBMCs causes hyperactivation of AKT-mTORC1 signalling and reduced expression of the T-cell homing genes KFL2 and S1PR1.

frames.text: Tbk1-flox mice44 were crossed with CD4-Cre transgenic mice (B6 genetic background, Jackson Laboratories), producing Tbk1+/+CD4-Cre (named WT) and Tbk1fl/flCD4-Cre (named Tbk1-TKO mice) mice

frames.text: tamoxifen (2 mg per mouse) in corn oil daily for four consecutive days to induce Cre
frames.verbose-text: with tamoxifen (2 mg per mouse) in corn oil daily for four consecutive days to induce Cre function.

frames.text: GFP expression
frames.verbose-text: After 48 h, the transduced cells were either enriched by flow cytometric cell sorting (based on GFP expression) for in vitro assays or directly transferred into T-cell-deficient mice for in vivo assays.PBMCs were isolated from human whole blood samples (purchased from The Gulf Coast Regional Blood Center) by Ficoll density gradient centrifugation.

frames.text: expression of Actb
frames.verbose-text: The expression of individual genes was calculated by a standard curve method and was normalized to the expression of Actb.
